description.narrative: Romer i Europa är i många fall offer för diskriminering och deras mänskliga rättigheter respekteras inte. Kränkningar mot romers mänskliga rättigheter tar sig ofta uttryck i form av hatbrott som ej bestraffas; att romer får sämre möjligheter till utbildning; att romer har sämre tillgång till boende; samt att romer diskrimineras av olika myndligheter och rättsvårdande instanser. European Roma Rights Centre (ERRC) arbetar mot kränkningar mot Romer genom att i) driva rättsfall i nationella domstolar liksom i Europadomstolen; ii) bedriva evidens-baserat påverkansarbete, ofta kopplat till de rättsfall som bedrivs, för att få tillstånd policyförändringar och uppmärksamma makthavare på den bristande tillämpningen av existerande lagar; iii) bedriva forskning för att kunna sprida information om diskriminering och för att kunna påverka makthavare; iv) bedriva kapacitetsutveckling av romska enskilda organisationer så att de blir medvetna om sina rättigheter och förmögna att försvara dem. ERRC har verksamhet i hela Europa, men Sida stödjer deras verksamhet i ODA-länder. Föreliggande program omfattar verksamhet i AL, BiH, KS, ME, MD, MK, RS, TR och UA.

The Roma community in Europe (by 'Roma' is meant all Roma, with or without intersecting identities, and people who do not identify themselves as Roma, but are still targets of anti-gypsyism, such as those identifying as Travellers, Sinti, Ashkali or Egyptian) is daily exposed to discrimination, harrassement and abuse for the mere fact that they are Roma. Those degradations are influenced and often worsened by other inequalities associated with gender, gender identity, disability, age, sexual orientation, socio-economic status, language, residence status, nationality and many other characteristics.
Roma face rights violations such as forced evictions, police brutality, and lack of access to safe drinking water, sanitation, and other basic services and facilities. Societies primed for prejudice often interpret these rights violations as appropriate and natural.
The cooperation partner European Roma Rights Centre (ERRC) is targeting anti-gypsyism by • exposing human rights abuse against all Roma (particularly Romani women), • litigating that abuse in court, and • mobilising Romani women and men to contest illegal practices, unjust power relations, environmental harm, and inequitable resource allocation, and to contribute to positive sustainable development.
The tools ERRC uses include; i) mobilisation - mobilising and empowering Roma and the Roma movement to use the legal system and justice mechanism to claim their rights, ii) research-based advocacy and communication targeting those responsible for securing the rights of Roma, iii) strategic litigation (public interest and testing litigation as well as representing individual litigants in Strasbourg or Geneva), iv) information and communication about ERRC work and achievemts in various media.
Anti-gypsyism is present throughout Europe (defined as CoE 47 member states). However, Sida can only target ODA-countries why the focus of Sida funds via ERRC are the Western Balkans, Turkey and Eastern Partnership countries. The ERRC program proposal includes AL, BiH, KS, MD, ME, MK, RS, TR and UA.

The ERRC's mission is to combat anti-gypsyism by; - exposing human rights abuse against all Roma, particularly Romani women, - litigating that abuse in court, and - mobilising Romani women and men; *to contest illegal practises, unjust power relations, environmental harm, and inequitable resource allocation, and *to contribute to positive sustainable development.

description.narrative: Following advocacy work by ERRC the Parliament in North Macedonia introduced a law on 7th October 2019 to ratify the Convention on the Reduction of Statelessness. The aim of the convention is to provide citizenship for all as a basic human right without discrimination. ERRC have campaigned together with partners since 2016 across the Western Balkans for Roma who are stateless or at risk of statelessness. The North Macedonian government have now formed an internal working group to overcome the lack of documentation and changing the law to improve birth registrations; providing a special legal status temporary ID number for undocumented persons; as well as introducing free legal aid, medical care and educational access for persons without documentation. ERRC's work with community mobilisation, to make Roma themselves use the law to solve problems of discrimination or human rights abuses, is complementing the heavier long-term cases with the European Court of HR and UN-bodies. During 2019, free legal aid was provided by, for example, a Roma-led law firm in Albania that assisted 123 cases. Another Roma-led CSO assisted 338 separate cases for Roma community members in Bitola, North Macedonia (a majority on segregated schooling). In Vojvodina Serbia, Roma law students placed in local law firms for legal practise, assisted 152 cases for free. By end of 2019, the total number of ERRC's active cases concerning ODA-countries pending before the courts were 91. By the end of 2018 it was 98, in 2017 it was 77 and by the end of 2016 it was 52. The largest subject matter in 2019 was police brutality followed by migration, environment and education. Litigants in the cases are predominately men (almost half) or 'mixed' (a third), while female litigants make up around a fifth. In 2019 ERRC moved out from the HQ in Budapest to a virtual office with a much smaller physical HQ in Brussels. To further complement the long-term cases with the European Court of HR and UN-bodies, ERRC have for 2020 added legal complaints brought by a critical mass of Roma people as a tool they work with. The theory of the "critical mass" approach is that complaints with large numbers of named complainants will make the current situation for Roma people more visible and real to judges, and in turn provoke the kinds of responses that are likely to force real change. During 2020 more than 1.500 Roma people in 3 countries (Serbia, North Macedonia, Albania) complained to public authorities about the discrimination they face. This shows to the institutions that the discrimination Roma people face is not a case of isolated incidents, but a systemic problem which requires their recognition and answer.
